clusters.title: Majority of Israelis opposed to two-state solution
clusters.neutral_headline: Global reactions to Palestinian state recognition

items.title: Majority of Israelis opposed to two-state solution
items.standfirst: A vast majority of countries represented at the United Nations already recognize a Palestinian state. With others now joining that number, Israel is becoming more and more isolated on the international stage. But public opinion inside Israel remains steadfastly opposed, with only a small minority supporting a two-state solution. FRANCE 24’s Claire Duhamel and Mohamed Farhat filed this report near the Israeli border with Gaza.
items.content: A vast majority of countries represented at the United Nations already recognize a Palestinian state. With others now joining that number, Israel is becoming more and more isolated on the international stage. But public opinion inside Israel remains steadfastly opposed, with only a small minority supporting a two-state solution. FRANCE 24’s Claire Duhamel and Mohamed Farhat filed this report near the Israeli border with Gaza.

items.title: Global reactions to Palestinian state recognition
items.standfirst: Several Western nations have formally recognised Palestine, drawing praise from Palestinians.
items.content: Several Western nations have formally recognised Palestine, drawing praise from Palestinians.

items.title: More Nations To Recognize Palestinian State At UN Conference
items.standfirst: A wave of countries recognizing Palestinian statehood around a special UN conference in New York is ramping up pressure on Israel and putting key allies at odds with the Trump administration. On Sunday, the UK, Australia, Canada, and Portugal officially recognized a Palestinian state, adding…
items.content: A wave of countries recognizing Palestinian statehood around a special UN conference in New York is ramping up pressure on Israel and putting key allies at odds with the Trump administration. On Sunday, the UK, Australia, Canada, and Portugal officially recognized a Palestinian state, adding…

items.title: World leaders meeting on Palestinian state as more countries join recognition calls
items.standfirst: World leaders are set to meet about a two-state solution as more countries officially recognize a Palestinian state and as the United Nations General Assembly kicks off in New York City. CBS News' Olivia Gazis has more.
items.content: World leaders are set to meet about a two-state solution as more countries officially recognize a Palestinian state and as the United Nations General Assembly kicks off in New York City. CBS News' Olivia Gazis has more.

items.title: Why recognise a Palestinian state?
items.standfirst: France is set to officially recognise the State of Palestine at the United Nations summit, joining countries such as the UK, Canada, Australia, and Portugal, which have already taken the step. The move is being framed as a symbolic gesture to support a two-state solution and push for renewed diplomatic efforts between Israel and Palestine. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has lashed out at the decision, insisting that a Palestinian state will not happen. FRANCE 24's Douglas Herbert ponder on why it is important to recognize a Palestinian state even though it's mainly symbolic.
items.content: France is set to officially recognise the State of Palestine at the United Nations summit, joining countries such as the UK, Canada, Australia, and Portugal, which have already taken the step. The move is being framed as a symbolic gesture to support a two-state solution and push for renewed diplomatic efforts between Israel and Palestine. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has lashed out at the decision, insisting that a Palestinian state will not happen. FRANCE 24's Douglas Herbert ponder on why it is important to recognize a Palestinian state even though it's mainly symbolic.

items.title: Italy cautious on Palestinian recognition as protests grow
items.standfirst: On Monday, cities across Italy witnessed pro-Palestinian protests, strikes, and blockades, following union calls to “denounce the genocide in Gaza” and push for diplomatic and economic sanctions against Israel. Meanwhile, while neighbouring countries such as the UK and France move to recognise Palestinian statehood, the Italian government has opted for a more cautious approach.
items.content: On Monday, cities across Italy witnessed pro-Palestinian protests, strikes, and blockades, following union calls to “denounce the genocide in Gaza” and push for diplomatic and economic sanctions against Israel. Meanwhile, while neighbouring countries such as the UK and France move to recognise Palestinian statehood, the Italian government has opted for a more cautious approach.

items.title: Israeli ministers call for West Bank annexation after recognition push

items.content: UK and three other countries formally recognised Palestine on Sunday

items.title: Disruption across Italy as tens of thousands protest against Gaza war
items.standfirst: Schools and stations closed and ports blocked in one of Europe’s biggest demonstrations opposing Israel’s offensiveTens of thousands of people have taken to the streets in dozens of cities across Italy – shutting schools, disrupting trains and blocking ports and roads – in one of Europe’s largest nationwide protests against Israel’s offensive in Gaza.The protests came as France and several other countries prepared to recognise Palestinian statehood at the UN general assembly on Monday after the UK, Australia, Portugal and Canada did so on Sunday. Continue reading...
items.content: Schools and stations closed and ports blocked in one of Europe’s biggest demonstrations opposing Israel’s offensiveTens of thousands of people have taken to the streets in dozens of cities across Italy – shutting schools, disrupting trains and blocking ports and roads – in one of Europe’s largest nationwide protests against Israel’s offensive in Gaza.The protests came as France and several other countries prepared to recognise Palestinian statehood at the UN general assembly on Monday after the UK, Australia, Portugal and Canada did so on Sunday. Continue reading...

items.title: French towns fly Palestinian flag despite gov’t ban before recognition
items.standfirst: The gesture comes as France prepares to recognise a Palestinian state at the UN General Assembly.
items.content: The gesture comes as France prepares to recognise a Palestinian state at the UN General Assembly.

items.title: France to recognise Palestine at the UN two-state solution conference
items.standfirst: France is set to officially recognise the State of Palestine at the United Nations General Assembly on Monday, September 22, 2025, joining the UK, Canada, Australia, and Portugal in this move. President Emmanuel Macron has defended the decision, stating that recognising Palestine is essential for isolating Hamas and promoting a two-state solution. FRANCE 24's correspondent Jessica Le Masurier sees this as a 'symbolic step towards peace rather than war', as Israel continues its offensive in the Gaza Strip.
items.content: France is set to officially recognise the State of Palestine at the United Nations General Assembly on Monday, September 22, 2025, joining the UK, Canada, Australia, and Portugal in this move. President Emmanuel Macron has defended the decision, stating that recognising Palestine is essential for isolating Hamas and promoting a two-state solution. FRANCE 24's correspondent Jessica Le Masurier sees this as a 'symbolic step towards peace rather than war', as Israel continues its offensive in the Gaza Strip.

items.title: Israel calls Palestine recognition 'absurd' and continues its expansion in the West Bank
items.standfirst: On 21 September 2025, the UK, Australia, Canada, Portugal, and France officially recognised the State of Palestine. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu condemned the move as an 'absurd prize for terrorism' and approved the E1 West Bank settlement project. Noga Tarnopolsky has the latest from Jerusalem.
items.content: On 21 September 2025, the UK, Australia, Canada, Portugal, and France officially recognised the State of Palestine. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu condemned the move as an 'absurd prize for terrorism' and approved the E1 West Bank settlement project. Noga Tarnopolsky has the latest from Jerusalem.

items.title: What's next after U.S. allies give a high-profile boost to a Palestinian state
items.standfirst: The U.K., Canada and Australia formally recognized a Palestinian state, sparking fury from Israel ahead of a UNGA summit amid the Gaza war.
items.content: The U.K., Canada and Australia formally recognized a Palestinian state, sparking fury from Israel ahead of a UNGA summit amid the Gaza war.

items.title: What does recognising a Palestinian state mean?
items.standfirst: The UK, Australia and Canada have recognised a Palestinian state, while France and other countries are set to do so in the coming days.
items.content: The UK, Australia and Canada have recognised a Palestinian state, while France and other countries are set to do so in the coming days.

items.title: U.K. formally recognizes Palestinian state
items.standfirst: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer announced the U.K. will recognize a Palestinian state after Israel failed to agree to a ceasefire in Gaza. Australia and Canada have made similar announcements ahead of the United Nations General Assembly.
items.content: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer announced the U.K. will recognize a Palestinian state after Israel failed to agree to a ceasefire in Gaza. Australia and Canada have made similar announcements ahead of the United Nations General Assembly.

items.title: Watch: Keir Starmer says UK recognises Palestinian state
items.standfirst: Prime Minister Starmer says the move will "revive the hope of peace" but Israel says it is "nothing but a reward for jihadist Hamas".
items.content: Prime Minister Starmer says the move will "revive the hope of peace" but Israel says it is "nothing but a reward for jihadist Hamas".

items.title: Why is the UK Recognising a Palestinian State Now?
items.standfirst: Starmer said in July the UK would shift position unless Israel met several conditions.
items.content: Starmer said in July the UK would shift position unless Israel met several conditions.

items.title: UK officially recognises Palestine as a state
items.standfirst: Sir Keir Starmer has announced the UK has officially recognised Palestine as a state.
items.content: Sir Keir Starmer has announced the UK has officially recognised Palestine as a state.

items.standfirst: Reports say writer, who has served six years for sharing a Facebook post, was given a presidential pardonMiddle East crisis – live updatesThe British-Egyptian human rights activist Alaa Abd el-Fattah will be released from jail after serving six years for sharing a Facebook post, Egyptian state media have reported.Egypt’s president, Abdel Fatah al-Sisi, granted him his freedom after intensive lobbying by the UK government and pressure from Egypt’s national human rights council. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: The British-Egyptian activist is one of six people whose sentences President Abdul Fattah al-Sisi commuted, according to state media.
items.content: The British-Egyptian activist is one of six people whose sentences President Abdul Fattah al-Sisi commuted, according to state media.

items.title: Egypt’s Sisi pardons jailed Egyptian-British activist Alaa Abdel Fattah
items.standfirst: Prominent Egyptian-British activist Alaa Abdel Fattah, who spent much of the past decade in jail, became a symbol of the struggle for human rights in Egypt. His pardon Monday by Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi followed a long campaign for his release, including a 10-month hunger strike by his activist and academic mother.
items.content: Prominent Egyptian-British activist Alaa Abdel Fattah, who spent much of the past decade in jail, became a symbol of the struggle for human rights in Egypt. His pardon Monday by Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi followed a long campaign for his release, including a 10-month hunger strike by his activist and academic mother.

items.title: Egypt grants presidential pardon to activist Alaa Abd el-Fattah
items.standfirst: He was arrested in 2019 in Egypt and sentenced in 2021 to five years in jail for "spreading false news".
items.content: He was arrested in 2019 in Egypt and sentenced in 2021 to five years in jail for "spreading false news".

items.title: Nvidia to invest $100bn in OpenAI, bringing the two AI firms together
items.standfirst: Deal will involve two transactions – OpenAI will pay Nvidia for chips, and the chipmaker will invest in the AI start-upNvidia, the chipmaking company, will invest up to $100bn in OpenAI and provide it with data center chips, the companies said on Monday, a tie-up between two of the highest-profile leaders in the global artificial intelligence race.The deal, which will see Nvidia start delivering chips as soon as late 2026, will involve two separate but intertwined transactions, according to a person close to OpenAI. The startup will pay Nvidia in cash for chips, and Nvidia will invest in OpenAI for non-controlling shares, the person said. Continue reading...
items.content: Deal will involve two transactions – OpenAI will pay Nvidia for chips, and the chipmaker will invest in the AI start-upNvidia, the chipmaking company, will invest up to $100bn in OpenAI and provide it with data center chips, the companies said on Monday, a tie-up between two of the highest-profile leaders in the global artificial intelligence race.The deal, which will see Nvidia start delivering chips as soon as late 2026, will involve two separate but intertwined transactions, according to a person close to OpenAI. The startup will pay Nvidia in cash for chips, and Nvidia will invest in OpenAI for non-controlling shares, the person said. Continue reading...

items.title: Arc’teryx fireworks display in Tibet prompts environmental outcry
items.standfirst: Outdoor brand says the Rising Dragon promotional event was out of line with its values after public criticismThe outdoor brand Arc’teryx has issued an apology after a promotional fireworks display in the Tibetan plateau led to an outcry over potential environmental damage.The promotional Rising Dragon high-altitude show involved long stretches of choreographed pyrotechnics and coloured smoke along snow-topped Himalayan ridgelines in the Tibetan region of Shigatse. The Canadian company, part-owned by China’s Anta Group, had partnered with a Chinese artist, Cai Guo-Qiang, who oversaw similar shows for the 2008 Beijing Olympics. Continue reading...
items.content: Outdoor brand says the Rising Dragon promotional event was out of line with its values after public criticismThe outdoor brand Arc’teryx has issued an apology after a promotional fireworks display in the Tibetan plateau led to an outcry over potential environmental damage.The promotional Rising Dragon high-altitude show involved long stretches of choreographed pyrotechnics and coloured smoke along snow-topped Himalayan ridgelines in the Tibetan region of Shigatse. The Canadian company, part-owned by China’s Anta Group, had partnered with a Chinese artist, Cai Guo-Qiang, who oversaw similar shows for the 2008 Beijing Olympics. Continue reading...

The new rule, announced last week and in effect as of Sunday, adds a one-time $100,000 fee for workers applying for a new H-1B visa. The…

items.title: Trump's New H-1B Visa Cost Could Hurt US Tech Companies
items.standfirst: US tech companies could have a harder time attracting foreign workers after President Donald Trump raised the application fee for H-1B visa's to $100,000. After Trump made the announcement late Friday, some companies had to tell affected employees to return to the US right away and to not travel overseas. Bloomberg's Michael Shepard reports. (Source: Bloomberg)
items.content: US tech companies could have a harder time attracting foreign workers after President Donald Trump raised the application fee for H-1B visa's to $100,000. After Trump made the announcement late Friday, some companies had to tell affected employees to return to the US right away and to not travel overseas. Bloomberg's Michael Shepard reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

items.title: Trump’s $100,000 H-1B visa fee could hurt US growth, economists warn
items.standfirst: Move is a blow to big tech companies, which rely heavily on visas to hire staff from overseas, particularly IndiaBusiness live – latest updatesDonald Trump’s decision to impose a $100,000 (£74,096) fee on H1-B visas for skilled foreign workers could hurt US economic growth, economists have warned.Trump signed a proclamation on Friday introducing the application fee for the H-1B visa, 60 times the current cost, in a move designed to encourage companies to hire more American workers. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump’s Fed pick doubles down on calls to aggressively cut interest rates
items.standfirst: Stephen Miran says rates should be below 3% by end of year and dismisses fears of US president’s tariffs stoking inflationStephen Miran, Donald Trump’s new appointee on the Federal Reserve’s interest-rate-setting board, has doubled down on his calls for the central bank to more aggressively cut interest rates.Last week, the Fed cut interest rates by a quarter point, bringing rates down to a range of 4% to 4.25% – the lowest it’s been since early 2023. Out of 12 voting board members, Miran was the only one to vote against the crowd. He wanted a half-point cut, not a quarter-point cut. Continue reading...
items.content: Stephen Miran says rates should be below 3% by end of year and dismisses fears of US president’s tariffs stoking inflationStephen Miran, Donald Trump’s new appointee on the Federal Reserve’s interest-rate-setting board, has doubled down on his calls for the central bank to more aggressively cut interest rates.Last week, the Fed cut interest rates by a quarter point, bringing rates down to a range of 4% to 4.25% – the lowest it’s been since early 2023. items.title: The Trump administration is expected to link autism to Tylenol use during pregnancy
items.standfirst: President Trump and HHS secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. are expected to tie autism to acetaminophen use during pregnancy, and present a cancer drug as a possible treatment. There is little credible scientific evidence for either claim.
items.content: President Trump and HHS secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. are expected to tie autism to acetaminophen use during pregnancy, and present a cancer drug as a possible treatment. There is little credible scientific evidence for either claim. (Image credit: Alex Wong)

clusters.title: France: Trial begins for Cédric Jubillar over wife’s disappearance
clusters.neutral_headline: France transfixed by murder trial without a body

items.title: France: Trial begins for Cédric Jubillar over wife’s disappearance
items.standfirst: The trial of Cédric Jubillar has started in France over the disappearance of his wife, Delphine, in December 2020. He is accused of her murder despite the body never being found and continues to claim his innocence. Evidence includes alleged threats, forensic traces, and inconsistencies in his phone records.
items.content: The trial of Cédric Jubillar has started in France over the disappearance of his wife, Delphine, in December 2020. He is accused of her murder despite the body never being found and continues to claim his innocence. Evidence includes alleged threats, forensic traces, and inconsistencies in his phone records.

items.title: France transfixed by murder trial without a body
items.standfirst: Cédric Jubillar has always denied killing his wife Delphine, who vanished in December 2020.
items.content: Cédric Jubillar has always denied killing his wife Delphine, who vanished in December 2020.

items.title: Trump says Rupert and Lachlan Murdoch likely part of US TikTok deal
items.standfirst: US president tells Fox News ‘a man named Lachlan is involved … that’s a very unusual name, Lachlan Murdoch’Rupert Murdoch and his son Lachlan Murdoch will probably be involved in the effort to buy TikTok in the US, Donald Trump said in an interview on Sunday.The president was asked about the status of the sale of the app during an interview with Peter Doocy on The Sunday Briefing on Fox News. Trump administration officials have signaled that a deal for the Chinese-owned social media platform was imminent, though there has been some confusion about the status of the agreement. Continue reading...
